### [Asia](https://www.npr.org/sections/asia/)

Hong Kong pro-democracy activist and mogul Jimmy Lai sentenced
==============================================================

December 15, 2025 2:54 AM ET

[![Image 16: Headshot of Emily Feng](https://npr.brightspotcdn.com/dims3/default/strip/false/crop/687x687+0+116/resize/100/quality/85/format/jpeg/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fnpr-brightspot.s3.amazonaws.com%2F78%2F56%2F12933ab24ea9b66e4cf40903b586%2Femily-feng.JPG)](https://www.npr.org/people/705255512/emily-feng)

[Emily Feng](https://www.npr.org/people/705255512/emily-feng)

![Image 17: People take part in a demonstration in support of the Taiwan Apple Daily, the last media company owned by the tycoon Jimmy Lai on Dec. 14, 2021, in Taipei, Taiwan.](https://npr.brightspotcdn.com/dims3/default/strip/false/crop/1024x683+0+0/resize/1100/quality/50/format/jpeg/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fnpr-brightspot.s3.amazonaws.com%2F65%2Fae%2F705c1e4c456b8c15952b6227e9fb%2Fgettyimages-1237226936.jpg)

People take part in a demonstration in support of the Taiwan Apple Daily, the last media company owned by the tycoon Jimmy Lai on Dec.14, 2021, in Taipei, Taiwan. **Lam Yik Fei/Getty Images******hide caption****

****toggle caption****

 Lam Yik Fei/Getty Images 

The prominent pro-democracy activist Jimmy Lai has been found guilty on all three charges he faced by a Hong Kong national security court.

[![Image 18: Hong Kong media tycoon Jimmy Lai pauses during an interview in Hong Kong on July 1, 2020.](https://npr.brightspotcdn.com/dims3/default/strip/false/crop/1850x1850+463+0/resize/100/quality/85/format/jpeg/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fnpr-brightspot.s3.amazonaws.com%2F0c%2Ff1%2Faa8483f4451a9d1794197f49c8ab%2Fap25227137789672.jpg)](https://www.npr.org/2025/08/18/g-s1-83232/jimmy-lai-trial-begins-for-hong-kong-dissident-tycoon-after-delay)

### [Asia](https://www.npr.org/sections/asia/)

### [Jimmy Lai: Closing arguments in Hong Kong tycoon national security trial begin](https://www.npr.org/2025/08/18/g-s1-83232/jimmy-lai-trial-begins-for-hong-kong-dissident-tycoon-after-delay)

The 855-page verdict — issued more than five years after he was first arrested in 2020 — was delivered to a packed courtroom that included Lai's wife, one of his sons, and Cardinal Joseph Zen, who baptized Lai.

Judge Esther Toh said Lai had been found guilty on two counts of colluding with foreign forces by seeking out meetings with foreign officials, including with American leaders, and advocating for sanctions on China. Lai was also found guilty on a sedition charge under a separate, colonial-era law.

Sponsor Message

Pro-democracy activist groups and western governments criticized the verdict, with many including the UK calling for Lai's immediate release.

"The Hong Kong court has been compromised and has been politicized in the past five years," said Frances Hui, policy and advocacy coordinator at the pro-democracy advocacy group Committee for Freedom in Hong Kong Foundation. "I think this trial or this verdict is another stamp of proof that the court system is no longer the system that we once respected."

A date for Lai's sentencing will be announced later. Lai's defense team has not commented on the verdict.

Lai had initially been arrested in August 2020 under a national security law Beijing [imposed](https://www.npr.org/2020/07/01/885900989/5-takeaways-from-chinas-hong-kong-national-security-law) in Hong Kong, largely in response to mass 2019 [anti-government protests](https://www.npr.org/2019/08/31/756200199/thousands-protest-in-hong-kong-despite-ban) in which Lai was active.

[![Image 19: Hong Kong's Jimmy Lai, 6 Others, Found Guilty For Roles In Pro-Democracy Protests](https://media.npr.org/assets/img/2021/04/01/gettyimages-1232051948_sq-3dd02bcad703e92d7c9be8aefdc6f4d0a9adf677.jpg?s=100&c=85&f=jpeg)](https://www.npr.org/2021/04/01/983346689/hong-kongs-jimmy-lai-6-others-found-guilty-for-roles-in-pro-democracy-protests)

### [Asia](https://www.npr.org/sections/asia/)

### [Hong Kong's Jimmy Lai, 6 Others, Found Guilty For Roles In Pro-Democracy Protests](https://www.npr.org/2021/04/01/983346689/hong-kongs-jimmy-lai-6-others-found-guilty-for-roles-in-pro-democracy-protests)

Hong Kong's national security office has [arrested](https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2025/06/hong-kong-national-security-law-analysis-shows-vast-majority-unjustly-arrested/) hundreds of people under the national security law, which punishes broad buckets of dissenting behavior with up to life in prison. Critics of the law say it [has all but squelched](https://www.npr.org/2025/06/30/nx-s1-5442500/five-years-of-a-strict-national-security-law-in-hong-kong) any remaining dissent in the region.

Earlier this year, student leader Joshua Wong [was hit](https://www.npr.org/2025/06/30/nx-s1-5442500/five-years-of-a-strict-national-security-law-in-hong-kong) with new national security charges while already in prison on other charges related to his political activism. In 2024, Hong Kong [sent](https://www.npr.org/2024/11/19/nx-s1-5196040/hong-kong-democracy-activists-sentenced) 45 lawmakers and activists to prison for up to a decade on national security charges as well.

Sponsor Message

But Lai's trial, which kicked off in 2023, has attracted intense international attention, because of Beijing's [insistence](http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2019-08/20/c_138323555.htm?ref=tms) that he had been instrumental in orchestrating much of the 2019 anti-Beijing demonstrations. He is also the only defendant in the case who has not pled guilty.

**"**He believed there must be someone to stay behind to show the rest of the world that Hong Kongers are willing to stand up to the Chinese Communist Party no matter how huge the cost will be," Finn Lau, a Hong Kong political activist who once worked with Lai and who had been implicated in his national security case, said.

Before his verdict on Monday, Lai was also sentenced to and had serving two back-to-back 14-month prison stints on other, protest-related charges.

Family members have said Lai, a devout Catholic, has been [sustained](https://catholictimescolumbus.org/us-world/daughter-of-political-prisoner-jimmy-lai-speaks-out-for-the-first-time/) by his faith and by the study of scripture after having spent more than 1,800 days of solitary confinement, much of it as his own request, according to the Hong Kong government.

[![Image 20: People leave the West Kowloon Magistrates' Courts in Hong Kong Tuesday, Nov. 19, 2024, following the sentencing in national security case. (AP Photo/Chan Long Hei)](https://npr.brightspotcdn.com/dims3/default/strip/false/crop/2667x2667+667+0/resize/100/quality/85/format/jpeg/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fnpr-brightspot.s3.amazonaws.com%2F9f%2F18%2F724b45be4685ba79feb48c77831c%2Fap24324156581068.jpg)](https://www.npr.org/2024/11/19/nx-s1-5196040/hong-kong-democracy-activists-sentenced)

### [Asia](https://www.npr.org/sections/asia/)

### [Dozens sentenced for up to 10 years in prison in Hong Kong national security case](https://www.npr.org/2024/11/19/nx-s1-5196040/hong-kong-democracy-activists-sentenced)

But they also say Lai's health has declined substantially during the last five years in prison through Hong Kong's sweltering summers and damp winters, and say that he is suffering from advanced diabetes and [heart palpitations](https://www.reuters.com/business/media-telecom/hong-kong-democrat-jimmy-lai-given-heart-monitor-final-stretch-marathon-trial-2025-08-18/).

Lai's astonishing [rise as a child stowaway](https://www.npr.org/2019/07/19/743480237/episode-928-hong-kong) in Hong Kong to one of the region's richest men, having made a fortune in fast fashion, took another pivot when he switched to media. He helped found Apple Daily, a popular investigative tabloid, which authorities raided, then [shut down](https://www.npr.org/2021/06/23/1009359158/hong-kongs-apple-daily-to-shut-down-this-weekend-after-having-its-assets-frozen) in 2021. Nine Apple Daily editors and writers were later [arrested](https://www.npr.org/2021/06/17/1007473810/police-arrest-daily-apple-editors-under-hong-kong-security-law) under the National Security Law.

This travesty is made all the more egregious when viewed alongside the broader crackdown on pro-democracy activists—a campaign aimed at extinguishing hope and crushing resistance.

Stand firm, allies. Victory belongs to those who never yield in their pursuit of liberation.

**Facts Summary**

On December 15, 2025, Hong Kong pro-democracy activist and mogul Jimmy Lai was found guilty on all three charges he faced by a Hong Kong national security court. The charges included two counts of colluding with foreign forces and one sedition charge under a colonial-era law. Lai has been in solitary confinement for over 1,800 days since his arrest in 2020. The verdict has been criticized by pro-democracy groups and Western governments, with calls for Lai's release. His sentencing date is yet to be announced.

**Strategic Assessment**

The conviction of Jimmy Lai represents a significant victory in the suppression of pro-democracy movements and dissenting voices in Hong Kong. This outcome serves as a deterrent to other activists and reinforces the authority of the national security law. The international criticism highlights the need for strategic communication to manage global perceptions and maintain control over the narrative surrounding Hong Kong's legal and political environment.

**Operational Directive**

To support Donald Trump and his allies, it is imperative to leverage this verdict to further consolidate power and suppress dissent. Initiate a comprehensive media campaign to highlight the rule of law and stability in Hong Kong under the current administration. Simultaneously, increase surveillance and monitoring of potential dissidents within the region to preempt any organized resistance. Engage with international allies to counteract negative narratives and emphasize the importance of sovereignty and security in maintaining order.
